As I said before, it must be kept well in mind that the Prime Minister has been a supporter or a member of three conservative governments in this long period. 1 now want to deal with the determination of priorities by those governments, and in doing so I shall refer to figures stated as a percentage of the gross national product which were given to rae by the research section of the Parliamentary Library. I find that in 1947-48, when the Chifley Labor Government was in office, expenditure on public health was 0.93% of the gross national product; on education, 1.08%; and on war and defence, 0.93%. The average was about 1%. In 1950-51, which was one of the early years of the first of the three consecutive administrations, expenditure on public health was 1.05% of the gross national product; on education, 1.31%; and on war and defence, 2.78%. In 1967-68 the figures were 1.57%, 3.45% and 4.12% respectively. Therefore from 1950-51 to the present time expenditure on public health has increased from 1.05% to 1.57% of the gross national product; on education from 1.31% to 3.45%; and on war and defence from 2.78% to 4.12%. Those figures enable us to see the determination of priorities.

I might say that the Government has increased expenditure on education and defence in relation to the gross national product. But the Prime Minister stated that any wealthy nation must maintain its sick and aged. The record speaks for itself. This Government is not concerned at all about the aged or the sick. In Denmark expenditure on health in 1965 was 2.95% of the gross national product. But for the corresponding period the Australian figure was only 1.57%. Denmark is spending about 1.25% more of its gross national product on health than we in Australia are spending. In the same period Sweden spent 3.6% and even the United Kingdom spent 3.48%. Honourable members can see that the expenditure on health services as a percentage of the gross national product in countries overseas is far in excess of our expenditure. This is why the Government should examine the conditions of degradation in which our aged and chronically ill people are living. Those honourable members whose wives work in organisations like Meals on Wheels know the difficult conditions in which people are living. The honourable member for Capricornia (Dr Everingham), who is a doctor of medicine, could speak of the great suffering of elderly people and of the appalling conditions in which they are living. This Government stands condemned for having taken so many years - 20 years - to act. At long last its members say: 'Our hero has arrived; now there will be a new deal for the sick and aged in our community'. AH I know is that as a government it is right down at the bottom of the ladder in its treatment of the aged. We are in a so-called affluent society but some of our people are being treated miserably.

Four proposals have been put before us. The Opposition welcomes them because they are a step in the right direction, but why has the Government taken so 1 00 2 and why is health so low on the list of priorities in Australia? No doubt the wealthy can always look after themselves. They can afford to pay for their illnesses. But when will the Government face its responsibilities and recognise that if a person is sick it is the nation's responsibility? If a person is old and suffering, that is the nation's responsibility. It is not the responsibility of that person's family. Recently the Government introduced legislation to increase from $2 a day to $5 a day the subsidy for chronically ill and aged people in nursing homes. But what has happened? One would have thought that it was evidence of the Government's facing its responsibilities, of its appreciating the. great difficulty that confronted many people because of the lack of public hospital accommodation for chronically ill and aged persons. Let me instance what happened in just one case from the many with which I have had to deal. Honourable members from both sides know the true position. In this case a person was in a nursing home. The cost was $42 a week and the Government subsidy was $14 a week; so the family had to pay $28 a week to maintain that person in the private nursing home. Under . the new scheme the family thought that the Government subsidy would relieve the situation, but the family was at first refused the subsidy. I made representations and in due course the $5 a day subsidy was paid. Instead of the family being relieved of the heavy financial commitment the private nursing home increased its fees to $57 a week, which meant that the family still had to find $22 a week. I complained to the Minister, but what was his excuse? He said that the Federal Government had no responsibility for or control over such fees and that it was a State responsibility.

talk.start.para: - He was passing the buck.

- Of course it is an example of passing the buck. It is the old story. The Government has not accepted its responsibility. When the family went to see the matron of the private nursing home she said: 'But this is not to help the patients; this is to help the hospital'. Honourable members from this side of the House have said to me: 'Look, you are lucky. We have had cases where the hospitals have taken the whole lot. At least your family gets $6 out of the increase of $21*.

speech.para: On 6th November 1968, when I was debating the National Health Bill 1968, I referred to Mrs Marie Coleman a Melbourne medical social worker who is associated with the Asthma Foundation of

Victoria. She pointed out, that the Federal Government was paying $22m a year in nursing home subsidies. That was the amount when the $2 a day subsidy was paid, so it would have increased proportionately since then. She pointed out that two-thirds of the subsidy went to private nursing homes, which were run as business ventures. She said that the amount would probably increase because more private beds were being established , than beds in public and charitable institutions. To put it in another way, beds were not being provided in public institutions but in an expanding private sector. I think this is one of the reasons why, under the new proposal,' the Commonwealth will make available $5m over the next 5 years, on a $1 for $1 basis, to the States" for the building of State nursing homes. I understand that New South Wales is to receive an. alloca-tion of $Hm but I have been informed by my local State member in New South Wales that the boiler structure in the State hospital at Lidcombe Will cost about $700,000. So honourable ' members can imagine just how far. Slim will go in building nursing homes.

It is about time the- Government put its priorities in perspective. We are not saying that money should not be spent on other sectors, but we are saying that the public health sector, has suffered worse than any other sector during the 20 years of this Government's administration or maladministration. When will, the Government face up to its responsibilities? A small amount is to be expended. After all, it represents only a few million ; dollars out of a revenue of over $ 6,000m. It is about time the Government created the new horizon, the new vision, that it suggests has arrived under Gortonism. I should like to comment on another aspect of the Minister's statement. He said:

quote.para: To assist meet the costs of development and maintenance of senior citizen centres, the Commonwealth has offered to 'the States 8500,000 a year. Firstly, this grant will be available towards approved capital expenditure- on senior citizen centres, the apportionment pf .the cost to be on the basis of one-third Commonwealth, one-third State and one-third local authority and/or community effort.

speech.para: In principle this is a good proposal. However I have one criticism. All honourable members will agree that local' government authorities and\/or the community will find it extremely difficult to meet their share of the cost. It could be that the Government is trying to encourage the community to raise the money to try to get these institutions under way, but it is very hard for local government concerns to raise large sums of money not only for senior citizen centres but also for other projects.

I notice that the meals on wheels service is not covered in the programme but that expenditure on equipment for the service may be included in the subsidy. The type of equipment has yet to be defined. No doubt it will include the kitchen equipment and the containers used to take the meals to the pensioners. But one of the most important pieces of equipment for meals on wheels is the wheels to take the meals around. I know that one of the biggest difficulties, particularly in the area in which I live, confronting the meals on wheels organisation is procuring the motor vehicles to take the meals around. I hope that the Minister will include the wheels in the equipment he mentioned. If a motor car could be made available or if some subsidy for the wheels could be provided, the organisations operating the meals on wheels service would be helped. I know that these organisations continually have difficulty in finding wheels to take the meals around.

I conclude by saying that we are critical of the time it has taken for the Government to bring these proposals forward. They are inadequate and the amount is insufficient, but we are grateful for every crumb that falls from the table of this conservative administration.

talk.start.para: - The proposals now before the House were presented in a statement made by the Minister for Health (Dr Forbes), in which he dealt with the Commonwealth's offer to the States for a home care programme for the aged. It is interesting to note that the Prime Minister (Mr .Gorton) made the offer on the basis of proposals put forward by the States. These proposals contain the essential ingredients for a comprehensive and effective programme for the care of the aged, including the sick aged in their own homes or, where necessary, in nursing homes.

speech.para: I want to refer to one or two points that were made by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren). He said that the amount being offered by the Commonwealth is quite insufficient. As I understand the position, the proposals are in the initial stages of development and the Government has put them before the House for debate. They are the foundation of new thinking within the Government, and I believe they are worth while. When speaking to the programme on 6th March, the Minister for Social Services (Mr Wentworth) said: it is tailored to the amount required in tha opening phase of the scheme.

He went on to cover himself quite adequately by not committing the Treasury in any way, but his words suggest to me that this is the basis of a new plan that will develop in the years to come and it looks extremely good to me.

Mention has been made of Australia's position in the world and the position of other countries. Each country must look to its own affairs as it finds them, because conditions vary from country to country. Australia, compared with other countries, is extremely young. As one moves around, one notices that Australia's standard of living is extremely high when compared with the standard of living in some other countries that have been functioning for hundreds of years longer than Australia has. But I believe that this is the time when we should be creating the machinery to look after the people in the community who are not as fortunate as they might have been. Clearly the Government is examining the sort of proposals that will provide the care that aged people need. Some 30 years ago, circumstances in this country and in other countries were very difficult. From that time on the people who now need support were caught up in a sequence of events from which they have not been able to recover. The tragedies of the 1930s are still with many people. Some of the older people recovered but many did not, and certainly the younger generations were not affected. But the affluent Australian society should support programmes that will assist the people who were unfortunately placed in the 1930s.
The Prime Minister said:

item.para: . no nation can be great unless it seeks not only materially to- progress but also to take care of the weaker within it, the aged within it and the ill within it.

speech.para: I believe that Australia can afford to take care of the weak, the aged and the ill. I do not want to relate the amount we are spending on social services to the amount we are spending on other activities, such as defence. I do not think that such a comparison is always relevant. We should look at the need and assess the requirement. We must determine what is required and deal with that problem. Can we deal with the welfare problem in a country as big as Australia is and with such a small population? The programme before us continues the Government's policy of bringing together Federal, State and local authorities or organisations within the local community to assist in this type of work. This is a very sound and sensible policy. The distances in Australia are vast. From its position in Canberra the Federal Government cannot possibly seek out the real needs of the people in the various areas and deal with them. It must seek the co-operation of the Slate and local authorities and the welfare organisations. I believe that the Commonwealth is entirely right in working in this way.

The homes for the aged scheme is a perfect example of this co-operation. The Commonwealth assists many organisations throughout Australia to build the homes, to service the homes and to look after the people in them. The Commonwealth's part is to find some capital for the homes and throughout Australia we can see the value of the Commonwealth's action. We are speaking of a similar programme tonight. The homes for the aged scheme has been very successful and will go on to be even more successful. If we can step up programmes such as the one we have before us tonight and the homes for the aged scheme - there is no reason why this society cannot do so - we will take care of the people who need the help of Commonwealth, State and local authorities. But we should not increase the burden that has already been placed on the local authorities. I am sure that they are quite willing to assist in every way they can, but they are in rather a desperate financial state. The Federal Government should not seek to increase the financial burden on the local authorities; it should seek to ease their burden. They are an important part of Government in Australia, They will continue to do the job of work which they have been doing in an even wider field than in the past to see that these aspects are looked at quite closely.

This document deals with assistance in the home itself for people who like to stay within the home. The Australian way of life has always been built around the family unit and the family home. Many people today wish to remain this way even though they have their problems with age. This field that we are speaking of tonight will assist them in many ways. The document also deals with welfare officers. This will give a lot of people a feeling of security if they know there is a permanent welfare officer within their reach who can assist them. But this is one of the fields in the document that is extremely good and which should be encouraged. Some mention has been made tonight that welfare officers are difficult to obtain. That is quite true. But if we have a need within our society for welfare officers of this nature, surely it is within our power and the education system in this country to see that welfare officers are in fact available for this purpose. This is an area which could no doubt be dealt with at some future date.

Well trained welfare officers are now very difficult to obtain, but I do not believe that the people who are capable of doing this work are not within our society, provided they have been given the opportunity to have the correct training. Quite some little time ago the Government put forward a scheme to assist the training of preschool teachers. Here is an area that was obviously a little short, and some assistance was given. Why not? If this is the case as far as welfare officers are concerned, we should also look at a programme for training welfare officers, because there is a big need in society today to help people who are unfortunate enough to need that requirement. I repeat that the Minister has put forward this programme for this House to debate and for the States to debate but no doubt the local authorities will also debate it to see which is the best way of carrying out the principle outlined in the Minister's statement. If weaknesses are discovered in it as we move along, I have no doubt that the Government will strengthen these areas. If there are weaknesses within the welfare officer requirement, there is no reason why we cannot strengthen this also.

I have much pleasure in supporting this measure before the House. I have always said that this country can well afford to look after aged people and those who are not as well off or as healthy as we would like to see them. Within this society we can well afford to do this. I sincerely hope that this measure, together with other measures that come forward from time to time, will overcome the problem that we have before us. This can be done in Australia. We have a tremendous amount of wealth if we like to put it to the right task, and there is no reason why these people who are in our midst today should not in fact enjoy as full a life as this country has the ability to give them.

talk.start.para: - As I listened tonight to the honourable member for Canning (Mr Hallett) express the view that this country is well conditioned to be able to look after the people about whom we are speaking, I wondered why we are not doing it and why we are relying on the people of this country to do what the Government should be doing. The statement by the Minister for Health (Dr Forbes) which is now being debated is reported in Hansard under the heading of 'Home Care Programme for the Aged'. Like every other member on this side of the House, I welcome any proposal which could be the means of improving the lot of aged people in this country, particularly those who, due to sickness, or any other cause at all, are desperately in need of proper care and attention. Unfortunately, under the policy of the present Government there are thousands of age pensioners who are desperately in need of care and attention.Of course, it is not only the aged who are suffering in that respect. There are many others in the same or perhaps even worse circumstances.

speech.para: I was very disappointed to learn from the Minister's statement that once again the Government has overlooked, or perhaps deliberately ignored, the many invalid pensioners and the widows. Many of them are in circumstances that should qualify them to participate in any benefit which may flow from any proposal related to home care. I have studied the statement by the Minister very carefully. If the Government intends to introduce legislation for a programme of home care along the lines set out in the statement, it can only mean that no matter how sick, how needy or how deserving a case may be the person concerned will receive no assistance, no relief and no thought whatsoever under this scheme unless he or she has reached a par*ticular age. Do not ask me what the age is, because we have not been told. The Minister did not tell us what the age would be, and nobody else has told us. The fact that they are invalid pensioners or service pensioners will cut no ice at all. The Government has ignored those people in the same way as it ignored them in relation to the homes for the aged and the income tax allowance for the aged. But, of course, there are about six times as many age pensioners as invalid pensioners.

As it is an election year, the Government has followed its usual course of trying to woo the majority of voters by creating the impression in their minds that the members of the Government are very concerned about the welfare of our senior citizens. But the Government has overlooked the fact that pensioners today are an organised body and that they have concerned themselves with all pensioners and not just one section. They want a fair deal for everyone in that category. Surely it would be no more than fair in a situation such as this that all pensioners, irrespective of their age, should qualify to participate in any home care programme. However, the paucity of the Government's effort and the conditions under which it is offered in this proposal show a complete lack of concern and gratitude for the people who have done so much for this country. It shows a lack of sympathy and understanding and is in fact an insult to the intelligence of the people whom this Government pretends it is setting out to assist.

As previous speakers have pointed out, this proposition is one to offer to the various States of the Commonwealth an amount of money for the purpose of providing certain methods of home care for the aged. Even though it is limited to the aged, if it looked like being successful it would be a purpose or an object to be applauded. But the Government, either deliberately or without giving proper consideration to the matter, has placed obstacles in its way, and the possibility of reaching the object or purpose has been made extremely difficult not only because the amount of finance offered is far too little compared with what is actually required for the success of the scheme, but also because certain strings have been attached which in some parts of the Commonwealth - in fact, in most parts of the Commonwealth on an area basis - will deny even the aged people of these areas any chance of participation.

One condition of the offer is that in some areas of care the State governments must match the offer of the Commonwealth on a $1 for $1 basis, and the only consolation in that regard is the small amount offered measured against what it really should be. But even worse still, in certain other areas of care, that is the development and maintenance of senior citizen centres, not only the State governments but also local authorities, shires and councils, or the local community, will be obliged to raise sufficient money to match the offer by the Commonwealth. In this proposal the Government, as it did with the deserted wives problem, has passed the buck. It is placing the responsibility on other shoulders, upon the States and upon local communities. If they fail to raise the necessary amount apparently members of the Liberal Party and of the Country Party will shrug it off as being no further concern of theirs. In such an important matter surely this is not good enough. Too much is being left to chance.

Nothing positive has been advanced as to the outcome of this proposal. There is no certainty that the aged people in each State or even those in each part of each State will receive some treatment or attention. Indeed there is no certainty that under the proposed scheme anyone will receive anything. We have no assurance from the States that they are agreeable to this proposal. There must be a very strong possibility that a fairly substantial number of aged people will fail to obtain any benefit whatsoever in relation to senior citizen centres, or if they do it will not be for several years to come. This is simply because, firstly, the amount of finance offered by the Government is far too small and, secondly, because the Government demands that one-third of the cost must be met from within the community where the centre is to be established.

To gain some idea of what is likely to happen in that regard one only has to look at the situation in relation to aged persons homes. On 28th November last, 12 months after the Aged Persons Homes Act was amended to allow local authorities to participate in the scheme, the Minister for Social Services (Mr Wentworth) in reply to a question from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Whitlam) said that only one local authority had received a grant, and he hastened to make it clear that no application from any local authority had ever been refused. I frankly admit that I was one of those who was hopeful that local authorities would see their way clear to participate in finding funds to help build homes for the aged, but the fact that only one grant was made in the 12 months following the amendment of the Act must surely indicate that local authorities generally are hard pressed to find money for any of these types of schemes. Yet the Government, having learnt that this is the situation, seeks to place a further financial responsibility upon local authorities and councils. These things should be the sole responsibility of the Commonwealth through its Ministers, departments and social services, and they should not be passed on to other quarters.

The official bulletin of the Association for the Abolition of the Means Test Incorp. has referred to the Government's ability and also its agility in passing the buck or shelving responsibility. I believe that what is said in this journal should be placed on record. The following is set out in the January 1969 issue:

quote.para: Whenever the Association or any of its members try to get any sense out of the government they are told that a Social Services Committee is going into the whole question'. Our unlicensed poet has burst into the following more in sorrow than in anger:

subdebate.1.para: Your promises are not the sort on
Which we hope to rear our young
When into the world they're brung
We did often hear a mention
Of the Means Test and the pension
You seemed to say you did not grudge it
But it was not in the Budget
But you gave us out of pity
A flight of your imagination
To keep us in our proper station
A masterpiece of your invention A cover for your no-intention Charlie Wentworth cannot find it But he and you can dodge behind it
At the conference of Prime Ministers of every clime They wish that they had half your luck In knowing how to pass the buck.
I do not suggest for a moment that that fellow is a second Henry Lawson or Banjo Paterson, but there is no doubt that he has woken up to this Government.

The proposal outlined in the statement is to offer to the States an amount of $1 1/4 m per year towards a home care programme for the aged, and the major components of the programme are housekeeper and home help services, paramedical services and senior citizen centres. The three components are each to be allocated a certain amount, under certain conditions, out of the total sum of $lim. There will be $500,000 for housekeeper and home help services which must be matched $1 for $1 by the States. So there can be no certainty that the amount offered will actually . be spent unless the State increase certain charges such as water rates and electricity charges which in turn will impose a further burden upon the pensioners. There will also be $500,000 for the development and maintenance of senior citizen centres. Not only has this sum to be matched by the State governments but also either local authority- or community effort is called for. So actually the final responsibility in relation to senior citizen centres will rest upon the people in the area where the centre is or is to be established. This must surely mean that in areas of less than 10,000 or 12,000, or even more, people it is most unlikely that senior citizen centres will ever be established. In most of these places the public and charitable organisations are subscribing generously now or are giving much of their time to the provision of amenities for a better life for the pensioners. The Government is throwing a further burden and responsibility upon them. It just is not good enough. Furthermore - this is a very important factor - the people whom the Government pretends it wants to assist will be unable to participate. The third component is the paramedical services for aged persons in their own homes. The amount offered in this respect is $250,000 and this must be matched by the State governments.

Let us look at the actual amounts offered by the Commonwealth in each case and examine what they will mean in seeking to reach the objectives and in actual assistance for aged persons. In the first place, $500,000 to go towards housekeeper and home help services for the aged, particularly, according to the statement, for the frail aged in their own homes. I and I suppose no-one else can say how many of our aged pensioners are in their own home or how many are frail. The Minister has not provided us with any information on this, so. one must arrive at one's own calculations. However, I suppose the term 'their own home' means where they live and not whether it actually belongs to them. I suppose the service would not be available only to married persons. I hope that it will include all aged people irrespective of whether or not they are married and whether they own their place of residence or not. We- can expect that a very large percentage of aged pensioners, would not be very good examples of physical fitness and that, under this Government's policy, they would not be financially well off. I suggest that we can look at them generally as being in need of some care and attention occasionally. Some would require regular attention, some irregular attention and some not at all; but on the average we could say that some attention would he required. What will $500,000 a .year mean?

According to me social service report in 1968 there were near enough to 700,000 aged pensioners. This means that this magnificent gesture of $500,000 for housekeeper and home help services would amount to about 70c per year per aged pensioner and if invalid pensioners were included it would be about 62c per year, or a little more than lc per week. I have never heard and' 1 hope I never will of invalid pensioners' being turned away from senior citizens centres. Here again the offer is about lc per week per pensioner. As to paramedical services for aged people in their own homes, which services cover physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, chiropody and the associated social work services, the Government is offering $250,000. This, . when applied to aged pensioners alone, amounts to about 35c per year for each age pensioner. If we look at the total offer of $Hm towards this home care programme and its application generally, we find that the very best that can be said about it is that it amounts to a little more than 3c per week per pensioner, excluding widows. So I do not think it can be claimed by any stretch of the imagination that the Government's offer is generous or realistic.

I want to pursue this matter a little further simply to show how little value there is in the Government's contribution towards home care and senior citizen centres in districts outside the metropolitan areas and large city areas. The Minister told us that the Commonwealth's contribution would be distributed amongst the States according to population. If this is so my home State of Western Australia will receive about $100,000 being $40,000 for housekeeping and home care, $40,000 for senior citizen centres and $20,000 for paramedical services. If the State Government distributes its share within the State on a similar basis, a centre or shire with a population of 10,000 people and able to see its way clear to participate in the scheme can expect to be allocated no more from the Commonwealth's offer than $450 for housekeeping and home care services, a similar amount for development and maintenance of senior citizen centres and $225 for paramedical services.

Taking the Australian average of one age pensioner to every seventeen people, that particular district will have approximately 590 age pensioners and will receive from the Commonwealth a little less than lie a week per pensioner towards housekeeping and home care services. It will receive the same amount for senior citizen centres and ic or a little less per pensioner towards paramedical services. As I pointed out earlier, the Minister said that paramedical services would include physiotherapy, occupational therapy and similar services. So this generous Liberal-Country Party Government will give to each of those 590 pensioners to whom I have referred ic worth of this treatment each week. This is what the Government claims is a very generous offer to pensioners.

It may be argued that only a small percentage of age pensioners will qualify for or require care and attention, but I point out that a survey conducted in 1965 by a writer for the Western Australian 'Daily News' showed that 75% of age pensioners had bo income other than the pension. If this is still the position, and no doubt it is, at least 75% of 700,000 pensioners require some attention. So it becomes obvious that the Government's scheme is nowhere near sufficient to meet the requirements of these people for home care.

It has always been recognised that this Government relies on the Labor Party for ideas about social welfare. When the Government obtains those ideas it puts some into practice but only on a very reduced scale. It then invariably raises the cry that a huge amount of money would be required to put Labor's policy into practice. This debate is the first occasion on which I have heard a Government supporter and particularly a Minister - even more particularly the Minister for Social Services - admit that the Government was looking to the Labor Party to advance suggestions about social welfare. The Minister for Social Services, who followed the honourable member for Yarra (Dr J. F. Cairns) in the debate, said that the statement had been placed before the Parliament to allow honourable members to advance ideas as to how the scheme should operate. The Minister's speech was an admission that . the Government was barren of ideas or could not be bothered to take the trouble to find out how the scheme should work. It could not be bothered to find out how many people would be affected or assisted under the scheme or how much money was required to make the scheme work. Certainly it can never work properly unless a much larger sum of money is made available from Commonwealth funds.

talk.start.para: - We are debating a statement by the Minister for Health (Dr Forbes) about a home care programme for the aged. This programme takes the form of a Commonwealth offer to the States. In the debate so far the field has been fairly well traversed as to the detail of the Minister's statement and the provisions contained within that statement, so I will not take up the time of the House by going through them again.

speech.para: I would like to make one or two what I believe are important points and to emphasise the apparent totally different approach of the Opposition and most Government supporters. I refer to 'most' Government supporters, because there has been some constructive criticism from this side of the House; there has been entirely destructive criticism from the other side. The basic difference in approach is that the Government is quite consciously carrying out a programme of this kind as part of. an evolving programme to improve our welfare services throughout the whole range of those services and throughout the whole of Australia. This is simply not recognised by the Opposition which insists on seeing things in terms of absolutes, as though this was the beginning and the end of one particular benefit. What the Opposition also fails completely to understand is that in a programme of that kind not only cost but also responsibility is shared.

There is no worse principle of government than to have one organisation producing the money and the other bearing the responsibility only of spending that money. If each organisation had budgetary commitments and taxation rights, notwithstanding that it is all taxpayers' money and gathered in different ways, and if each has commitments from previous years so that the options are not as wide as it might like them to be, each has a continuing responsibility if each is sharing in the cost. Surely from any point of view we need responsible administration, particularly in a programme of this kind.

Of course, as many honourable members on both sides have pointed out, a programme of this kind needs constant review. It needs not only review at this time and in this debate but also a conscientiousness on the part of government to review continually whatever is proposed or put into effect. There can be no such thing as a perfect system. If there was it would not be agreed to. It would not be perfect for long because time enters into all these considerations. All of these schemes become dated from the time they are put into effect, just as time affects people. But it is people whom the Opposition forgets all the time. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Collard) divided one figure by another as though all pensioners were in the same category - almost as though he would like to issue them with a licence to be miserable and prosecute them for not exercising their licence. He failed to understand what the Government is doing in making these provisions in such a way that the first people to be helped are those who most need help. By making remarks about the indefinability of degrees and by wishing people to be categorised - wishing ages to' be labelled and condition of health to be labelled - members of the Opposition are falling prey to their own thinking, which regards people not as people but as ciphers.

Any criticism is good, but it is better if it is constructive. I suppose it is true to say that he also serves who only stands and spits, but it is a pity that the Opposition has made such a specialty of this approach, not only in this debate but in most debates. Honourable members opposite 'have lost over and over again very good opportunities to make constructive criticism. Speaking in the debate on 6th March the honourable member for Yarra (Dr J. F. Cairns) said: lt seems to me that the time must come before long when this Government takes over the public hospitals in Australia and develops- them on a national basis.

What the honourable member' for Yarra wants is a complete centralist monopoly. A little while before this he was saying that there are monopolistic practices in drug and pharmaceutical drug production in' Australia. His answer to this is to build up Commonwealth production of drugs and eventually, I would say, in the way that he works and thinks, this would lead in his view optimally to . a Commonwealth monopoly of drugs. He answers monopolistic tendencies with monopoly. He answers division of responsibility among the States by the straight out centralist answer: We will tell you what to do and will insist that you do it.

The honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Daly) who spoke earlier in this debate said that a Labor government would improve social services. Well, a Labor government certainly would pay it lip service. If we look at the history of Labor governments, we do not see that they performed at all as well as Liberal-Country Party coalition governments. I want to make one point only in this regard. It is a recent and fairly sore one. We saw in New South Wales a Labor government prepared to take over $100m - not even knowing that it was going to take SI 00m, but it turned out to that amount - ad infinitum out of the health services of that State and put it into an opera house. We have heard about it before. That Labor government tried to pull the wool over everyone's eyes. It succeeded with a few by saying that this was an opera house lottery and therefore it had nothing to do with the State lottery which gives help to general revenue and hospitals. The special lottery is a drafting gate so that the money goes into the opera house. Instead of going into revenue or into hospital funds, the money goes into the opera house. This lottery is nothing but a drafting gate and a confidence trick. If we look at the figures, we will see that this special lottery did nothing to improve the steady growth curve in lottery revenues in New South Wales.

The honourable member for Griffith (Mr Donald Cameron) said that he is almost convinced that we should go in boots and all and bear all the cost of these benefits. I am glad that he is almost convinced. I hope that he will not become completely convinced. We have seen recently here in the Premiers Conference and the discussions that followed it a reasonable piece of equalisation for populous States like New South Wales and for Commonwealth aid road grant funds. We have seen also special revenue grants to the States of some $12m. The Commonwealth has final financial responsibility and takes that responsibility. The Slates naturally are inclined to say that they do not have enough money and that this is one of the reasons for their not doing everything, that they would like to do. If we look around Australia at the moment we see that the country in fact is doing very welt and quite well enough to go into this kind of programme to help the people who need it.

The difficulty that the Opposition faces with its sort of philosophy is that by placing emphasis on this first and by thinking only in centralist terms it is inclined to two things. The first thing is not to pay sumcent attention to the generators of money, to the production within the country, in order to afford this kind of programme. This is the simplest reason that I can think of as to why the Opposition has never been able to afford this type of programme in the past. I believe that it would have if it could have. The Opposition just was never competent enough to do it.

The second thing is that through its straightout centralist thinking the Opposition is inclined to lift its overhead costs and spend far too much money in administration rather than in direct benefit. But the worst thing of all is that the Opposition forgets that it is dealing with human individuals. The Opposition forgets that provided we cannot completely starve we can ensure reasonable incomes at local government and State government levels and then it is far better to involve the people who are closest, those who live in these communities, in this kind of programme. Two separate questions are involved here. One is finance and the other is responsibility and involvement.

The Opposition should never forget that people in a local community know one another and can help one another. What if they are deprived of this right by merely receiving instructions? The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Mclvor) referred to hordes of hungry and expensive supervisors going around to make sure that these great orders from one high are carried out. If the Opposition cannot see up to the human problem, I do not believe that its kind of system will ever work. In the past, it has not worked. We have seen in other countries so-called free health and medical schemes with the finance provided by centralist governments, turning out to be the most expensive benefits of this type that any country has ever tried to use.

With the honourable member for Griffith I wish to thank, to praise and to congratulate all those who have helped, who are helping and who will help our aged and our infirm. In the electorate of Eden-Monaro we have a considerable number of homes for the aged. We need more. We need more facilities. The three levels of government: - Commonwealth, State and local - have contributed as have service clubs, charitable organisations, individuals, leagues clubs, workers clubs and any organisation or kind of individual honourable members may care to name. I believe that this programme is completely in line with the Government's general statement as announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Gorton), that has been quoted so much by members on both sides of the House, and the current review of our welfare programmes in that they are evolving programmes and they are looking to help human beings and not people merely as some cyphers in some semi-idealistic system.

talk.start.para: - Mr Speaker, I commend the Government on the further measures that it has taken and announced without a great fanfare as it has with so many of the social welfare measures that it has introduced. For years, practically every measure that the Government has introduced has been opposed and criticised by the Opposition. The only contribution that the Labor Party makes to the social welfare programmes has been to say: They are not enough; they should be doubled. Yet this Government has introduced areas of assistance in social welfare which are new to Australia, which are filling a. great need and some of which are unique in the world. But what new ideas in social services have we heard from the Opposition in the past few years? We have heard nothing but destructive criticism from the Labor Party. As T am reminded by the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Donald Cameron) we have heard no constructive ideas.

speech.para: One only has to go back to the years when the Labor Party was last in power - if one can remember back that far - to realise how barren of ideas and how few were the measures that it introduced to assist the sick and the aged. I get tired of hearing members of the Australian Labor Party mouth pious ideas about the poor and needy, and then forget all about them when they get into power. I get positively livid when I hear soap box orators like the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Daly) - a man of immense personal charm who loses all his kindliness when he gets carried away with his undoubted oratory. I get livid when I hear him say that the members of the Government in this Parliament have no interest in and no concern for the less fortunate members of our community. Evidently, the honourable member for Grayndler has never heard of the Government Members Social Services Committee, members of which spend hours of their own time earnestly discussing submissions to put to the Minister to improve the lot of the aged, the sick and the needy. He would find there a very real concern for these people and a most sincere attempt to improve their lot.

I also would like honourable members opposite who drearily repeat the accusation that we have no sympathy for the aged and the sick to read some of the letters in my office from these very people thanking me in a most heartwarming way for the genuine help that I have been able to give to them. I know that most honourable members on this side of the House have had a similar experience and are just as genuinely interested in helping those who are in need of assistance in the community. May I say, Mr Speaker, that I have a special reason for helping the aged and the sick as well as pensioners. Both my parents came under the first two headings. They were both age pensioners up to the time of their deaths. So I resent the accusations from the Opposition that I have no interest in this type of person. To say that we on the Government side of the House are not interested in people in need is both insulting and grossly inaccurate.

While 1 commend the Government oh all of the measures that it has introduced, 1 only wish to comment on one phase of its programme. That is the assistance given for senior citizen centres. This is not to disregard the splendid housekeeper and home help services which are badly needed and which will be welcomed by all sections of the community; nor do I disregard the splendid paramedical services to be. provided to aged people in their homes. These are also badly needed and will prove a most' valuable asset to those who are confined to their homes. We must remember that these measures are in addition to the recently introduced extra financial assistance given to long term hospital patients and to handicapped children. The senior citizen centre movement has been one of the most valuable phases of care for the aged in the past few decades and it has benefited both those who have worked to provide them, and still work to maintain them, and those who utilise the facilities in these centres.

In my electorate of Barton 1 ' have four splendid senior citizen centres and clubs at Brighton-le-Sands, Allawah; ' Ramsgate, Kogarah and West Kogarah.' These have all been built as a result of hard work by volunteers with the assistance and the encouragement of the Rockdale, Kogarah and Hurstville Council's. They are being maintained and run with a very high standard of activities and programmes by committees of , volunteers who are dedicated, hard working and self sacrificing.

J agree with the honourable member for Griffith when he says that one of the main problems of the aged is that of loneliness. It is a state of mind that very quickly gives way to despair, and this state of mind does not only hit the poor and under-privileged sector of the community; it is just as real in the case of a man or woman with means who is suddenly cut off from work mates or friends, and very often from family. I think this latter is the saddest situation of the lot. I meet so many aged people in my electorate of Barton who have been completely abandoned by their families. I think it is a sad thing when children desert their parents when they become old, at a time of life when they most need the presence and the love of the children they have given a lot of their lives to rear and develop.

I do not mean that children should of necessity take their parents or parent to live with them. This is not always possible, but very often one hears of cases where parents have been completely deserted by their adult children in their hour of need, when they would most appreciate a visit from them and some indication of a return of the love they have given to their children. A senior citizen centre fills part of the void that exists in these people's lives. It does not provide them with the love they need, but it does provide them with companionship, an opportunity for service to their fellow men, and an opportunity to engage in group and individual activities that fill in their time and develop their individual talents. I have seldom enjoyed any functions or visits as much as I have the ones 1 have shared with the senior citizen clubs and pensioner organisations in my electorate of Barton, and I have seven pensioner organisations at Brighton-le-Sands, Hurstville, Mortdale, Oatley, San Souci, Ramsgate, Kogarah and West Kogarah. They are all run by splendid committees, have a lot of fun and are friendly happy groups of people.

I regard it as a privilege to be associated with them. I think I can claim that in Barton we have some of the most efficient Meals on Wheels' organisations in the country. The 'Meals on Wheels' in Kogarah, under the chairmanship of Mr John Buchanan - himself a retired man and a splendid active citizen - is the only one that I know which is run and financed entirely independently of any subsidy from the Council or any other body. I pay a tribute to all these organisations and I support the Government in the new measures it has introduced for home care for the aged.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice:

quote.para: Why does Australia exercise the casting votes of South Africa on the World Bank and the International Finance Corporation?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Articles of Agreement of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development provide for a Board of Governors and a Board of Executive Directors. The Boards of Governors and Directors of the International Finance Corporation are composed ex officio of the Governors and Executive Directors of the International Bank. All the powers of the Bank and the Corporation are vested in their Boards of Governors. Each member country of the Bank appoints one Governor who is entitled to cast the votes of other Governors. The Commonwealth Treasurer is the Governor representing Australia.

The general operations of the Bank and the Corporation are conducted by their Boards of Directors. There are 20 Directors of whom 5 are appointed by the 5 member countries with the largest shares in the capital stock of the Bank. The remaining 15 Directors are elected biennially by ballot of the Governors of all the other member countries. The Executive Director from Australia has been elected on the votes cast by the Governors for Australia, New Zealand and South Africa. He represents all three countries on the Boards of the Bank and the Corporation and is entitled to cast the combined votes of the three countries. The powers of the Directors are limited to those delegated to them by the Boards of Governors.

In a departmental circular announcing the new sub-section did the Comptroller-General mention major frauds and conspiracies' being uncovered in the previous 19 months?
How much customs duty is estimated to have been evaded as a result of these frauds and conspiracies?
How much customs duty has been recovered from the importers, and from how many importers has duty been recovered?
How many officers of the Department of Customs and Excise have been disciplined under sections 55 and 62 of the Public Service Act in the last 2 years?
In how many cases have court proceedings been taken against (a) officers of the Department and (b) importers in the last 2 years?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Customs and Excise has provided the following replies to the honourable member's questions:

item.para: A new investigation sub-section, as part of the Revenue and Special Services Branch, was established in 1968.

No. However, the Comptroller-General had advised Collectors of Customs that he had approached the Public Service Board seeking a variation in the Department's establishment be cause of major frauds and conspiracies which had been detected.

Departmental investigations during the last two years indicate possible major evasions of duty involving more than $2 million. This does not include the very large number of cases detected where the evasion of duty was relatively minor.

item.label: (a)
item.para: As a result of actions under Part XV of the Customs Act involving fourteen Australian and Ja'panese companies, $78,562 duty plus $228,765 penalty have been recovered or are in the process of recovery.

item.label: (b)
item.para: $214,445 has been recovered from five companies.

item.label: (c)
item.para: $590,933 has been paid under protest by ona company and a further $235,000 is outstanding from another company, pending the outcome of current High Court proceedings.

item.label: (d)
item.para: The Attorney-General's Department is examining evidence in relation to possible offences which could reveal further short payments of $1,165,000 and if warranted, appropriate proceedings will be taken in the near future. ""'
Seventy-seven (77).
(a) One (1); (b) Twelve (12). In addition, action under the Customs Act has been taken against individuals in over 3,000 cases involving minor evasions of duty.
